data.text: Is Ride with GPS better than Komoot?

Is ride with gps or Komoot better? I’ve used komoot premium for 2 years. I like it but it has sent me on routes that are made of private roads and the bike route maps are out of date where I live. I’m up for renewal in august and I’m just seeing if it’s worth changing.

I don't have a lot of experience with Komoot, but when I was trying out different apps when I first got introduced to it, I found RidewithGPS more intuitive and easy to plot my own route. Komoot can be good for telling you where the gravel roads are though, to the plot a route from that. RidewithGPS only tells you it's gravel once you click in it.
data.author: Victoria James

data.text:
komoot has been very good. I like the different sport maps but my city has installed a lot of bike lanes and roads with wide shoulders. Komoot generally has done ok at keeping me off of busy streets but it needs to be updated with the newer maps. I haven’t seen how ride with gps does but I do like the cámara feature and it’s sponsored by Adventurecycling.org and I just subscribed to them. It does appear that komoot has more support over seas which is cool because I do travel to Europe whenever I can.
Discover What Awaits
adventurecycling.org
data.author: Justin Patrick

data.text: This is the endless debate. Bikemap is my favorite. Komoot is too challenging for my brain.
data.author: Francesca Cohn

data.text: Why bother? As Lao Tzu stated: "A good traveller has no fixed plans, and is not intent on arriving". Please remember when you're touring that there is no such thing as 'being lost'. You're just exploring where you happen to be.
data.author: Alan Cook

data.text: 🙄
data.author: Justin Ward

data.text: Not exactly the answer the OP was looking for but, I like it anyway 😅
data.author: Andre Byrne

data.text: except we want to remain on roads that are safe for bikes.
data.author: Janice Eddington

data.text: There are no 'roads' (i.e. where there other vehicles) safe for cyclists. Any road where there is other traffic is dangerous for cyclists. How does your comment relate in any way to what I'd written? There is no connection at all.
data.author: Alan Cook

data.text: I am finding that I am using RWGPS more than in the past. BUT when none of the apps will map the way I want to go because the "route" does not exist in their computer, drives me nuts. I had 4 apps open trying to map out my ride and none of them would let me get on the road I wanted and took me 6 blocks out of the way.
data.author: Janice Eddington

data.text: A few years ago komoot did take me through a private manor , I've been told it now distinguishes between foot paths & cycling paths ,I find the street view really handy .
data.author: Kevin Dean

data.text: The route planning website cycle.travel gives pretty good routes prioritising cycle tracks and quieter roads. I use it to plan, then export the .gpx and drop it into ride with GPS to use it.
data.author: Roger Sparkes

data.text: i'm not taking a laptop with me and planning routes on a website on my very small cell Phone is not an option. So I'm looking for an app that will plan the route for me. Avery app that I have looked upon for now missed the option "avoid hills" 😀. (that tells something about my condition and experience 😉)
data.author: Lidwien Fokkinga

data.text: Mapout has a criteria for hills and a criteria for small/medium/big roads.
data.author: Tommy Kennedy

data.text: Following!
data.author: Lidwien Fokkinga

data.text: I think it is very good I’ve opted for buying at a low price the world maps which is one price for life. Even if you do not use their tours it is useful to record your own for future use especially if they are good.
data.author: Robbie Benstead

data.text: I have the premium edition of ride with gps and I’m a fan. I can explore routes that others have ridden and specify gravel. I love the turn by turn instructions. I’ve used this a lot when traveling with my bike in unfamiliar places.
data.author: Jon Bergmann

data.text: Get a Garmin
data.author: George Homer

data.text: I used Komoot for several years and did not like ridewithgps when it first came out. I switched last year as RWGPS has many more options and has improved a great deal. Premium is expensive though.
data.author: Timothy Dale

data.text: I'm a big fan of komoot but I always use the 'road cycling' setting as the 'bike touring' setting tends to send you down more questionable paths. I always cross reference the route with Google maps too, just briefly. Although you can now access street view on komoot which is great.
data.author: Sarah Vickers

data.text: agree 100% tho don't you find that those bad komoot routes are the ones you remember and laugh about!
data.author: Debs Mutton

data.text: Ride with GPS
data.author: Patricia Huckins Leathrum

data.text: I use Komoot with World Maps, cannot see any great benefit with premium. I did use Ride With GPS, it's good and most of the "serious" cyclists I know use it rather than Komoot but the expense deters me. The only real issue I have had with Komoot is that it under states elevations on planned routes. I really like the turn by turn voice navigation.
data.author: Mick Hine

data.text: rwgps now has this
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: You are right and I used it whilst I subscribed to RWGPS but I paid £19.99 for my Komoot lifetime world maps subscription. Unless it's changed turn by turn voice only comes with the subscription RWGPS, which was about £10 a month when I used it, and I think you still get this on Komoot if u just use the free version.
data.author: Mick Hine

data.text: if you go for the full package kamoot is $60 and rwgps is $70 per year, but kamoot add insurance and other benifits
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: thanks for clarifying that. For myself I am happy with what I have got and it meets my needs 🙂👍. Got too many subscriptions already, Netflix, Amazon Prime etc, etc.
data.author: Mick Hine

data.text: 😂you and me both
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: I use Komoot to plan my routes, then upload the routes to my Wahoo ELEMNT Roam, because running Komoot on my iPhone kills the battery fast. Most of my riding is in the metro area of a major city, so Komoot’s road and bike path detail is invaluable.
data.author: Adam Whisner

data.text: Getting lost can be fun
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: not as much on busy roads with no shoulders like many are here in the states.
data.author: Justin Patrick

data.text: oh no get out of the USA immediately
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: America, RWGPS. In Europe, I think others are very competitive.
data.author: Roy Onabike

data.text: Forget both of those and use cycle.travel
data.author: Paul Skillend

data.text: RWGPS has the same issue with private roads… so much so I canceled a 2 week tour due to needing more research on roads. I lost faith in my track when RWGPS had me starting out on a road 2 miles from my house that I had never seen before on a mountain I hike a lot. After a quick drive to the road beginning I quickly learned my suspension was correct, so drove up to the next intersection of a known major Forest Service Road, and saw that my next intersection was also private property… I did this three more times, to find the same problem covering my first half day… since starting day 2 was going to be all unexplored area to me and I was on a deadline for the first week, I bailed and drove to my destination instead of riding.
data.author: Mike Rose

data.text: I just use Komoot Free. I usually plan my routes prior.
data.author: Ian Stapo

data.text: Riding RTW with komoot and very happy. We always look over the route, look at it on street view if possible. Not saying we haven't had the odd problem but when we have compared others it seems better. Cycle.travel very good in UK and free tho.
data.author: Debs Mutton

data.text: Just got back from Denmark doing part of the North Sea Cycle route and used Naviki for the first time. Really good - will be using it regularly from now on instead of Komoot
data.author: Simon Warner

data.text: I must admit sometimes the off-road paths are hard to find￼
data.author: Robbie Benstead

data.text: Mapy.cz
data.author: Edin Čolić

data.text: I am still deciding. for me at the moment is the ability to transfer the planned route and "ALL the extra bits" to my Garmin. Garmin has a battery life far longer than any phone. (in low power mode the 1040 estimates 84 hours + what ever it can get from the sun. Which on a sunny day can be 25%. - my testing results). "ALL the extra bits" in RWGPS, you can add your own points of interest, and trail notes / manual cue cards . Some of these appear on the Garmin ! this is the bit i am working on / testing. For example i wan to know when i am near a drinking fountain to fill my bottles. Komoot can do this with build in points of interest, but you cant add your own. RWGPS you can add, but it does not have a library of existing ones (not found it at least). Komoot can transfer to Garmin, but does not bring POIs with it as part of the GPX export file. BTW if anyone have experience on this please share
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: I just rode Athens to Geneva mostly using a combination of Komoot, Guru maps and Google maps. Komoot got things very wrong on some occasions and very right on others. By the time I was in Italy and Switz I dumped it. Guru has wonderfully clear contour lines is incredibly clear. Learning how to really finesse Komoot took a while, but its not bad. The most annoying thing is the voice commands.
data.author: Henry Thompson
